text: In the twenty-seventh year of King Jeroboam’s reign over Israel, Amaziah’s son Azariah became king over Judah.

He <st data-num="01961" class="">was</st> <st data-num="08337 06240">sixteen</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">years</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">old</st> when he began to <st data-num="04427" class="">reign</st>, and he <st data-num="04427" class="">reigned</st> for <st data-num="02572 08147" class="">52</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">years</st> in <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>.<n id="1" /> His <st data-num="0517" class="">mother’s</st> <st data-num="08034" class="">name</st> was <st data-num="03203" class="">Jecholiah</st>, who was from <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>.
He did what the Lord approved, just as his father Amaziah had done.

<st data-num="07535" class="">But</st> the <st data-num="01116" class="">high places</st> were <st data-num="03808" class="">not</st> <st data-num="05493" class="">eliminated</st>; the <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> <st data-num="05750" class="">continued</st> to <st data-num="02076" class="">offer sacrifices</st> and <st data-num="06999" class="">burn incense</st> on the <st data-num="01116" class="">high places</st>.

The Lord afflicted the king with an illness; he suffered from a skin disease until the day he died. He lived in separate quarters, while his son Jotham was in charge of the palace and ruled over the people of the land.
The rest of the events of Azariah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
Azariah passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Jotham replaced him as king.
In the thirty-eighth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Jeroboam’s son Zechariah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for six months.
He did evil in the sight of the Lord, as his ancestors had done. He did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.

<st data-num="07967" class="">Shallum</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="03003" class="">Jabesh</st> <st data-num="07194" class="">conspired</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">against</st> him; he <st data-num="05221 04191">assassinated</st> him in <st data-num="02991" class="">Ibleam</st><n id="1" /> and <st data-num="08478" class="">took</st> his <st data-num="08478" class="">place</st> as <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st>.

The <st data-num="03499" class="">rest</st> of the <st data-num="01697" class="">events</st> of <st data-num="02148" class="">Zechariah’s</st> reign <st data-num="02009" class="">are</st> <st data-num="03789" class="">recorded</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">in</st> the <st data-num="05612" class="">scroll</st> called the <st data-num="01697 03117">Annals</st> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">Kings</st> of <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>.<n id="1" />
His assassination fulfilled the Lord’s message to Jehu, “Four generations of your descendants will rule on Israel’s throne.” And that is how it happened.
Shallum son of Jabesh became king in the thirty-ninth year of King Uzziah’s reign over Judah. He reigned for one month in Samaria.

<st data-num="04505" class="">Menahem</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="01424" class="">Gadi</st> <st data-num="05927" class="">went up</st> from <st data-num="08656" class="">Tirzah</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">to</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="08111" class="">Samaria</st> and <st data-num="05221" class="">attacked</st> <st data-num="07967" class="">Shallum</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="03003 08111">Jabesh</st>.<n id="2" /> He <st data-num="04191" class="">killed</st> him and <st data-num="08478" class="">took</st> his <st data-num="08478" class="">place</st> as <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st>.

The <st data-num="03499" class="">rest</st> of the <st data-num="01697" class="">events</st> of <st data-num="07967" class="">Shallum’s</st> reign, including the <st data-num="07195 0834">conspiracy</st> he <st data-num="07194" class="">organized</st>, <st data-num="02009" class="">are</st> <st data-num="03789" class="">recorded</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">in</st> the <st data-num="05612" class="">scroll</st> called the <st data-num="01697 03117">Annals</st> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">Kings</st> of <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>.<n id="1" />

At that time Menahem came from Tirzah and attacked Tiphsah. He struck down all who lived in the city and the surrounding territory, because they would not surrender. He even ripped open the pregnant women.
In the thirty-ninth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Menahem son of Gadi became king over Israel. He reigned for 10 years in Samaria.

He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who encouraged Israel to sin.

During his reign,

<st data-num="06322" class="">Pul</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="0935 05921">invaded</st> the <st data-num="0776" class="">land</st>, and <st data-num="04505" class="">Menahem</st> <st data-num="05414" class="">paid</st><n id="2" /> <st data-num="06322" class="">him</st><n id="3" /> <st data-num="0505" class="">1,000</st> <st data-num="03603" class="">talents</st><n id="4" /> of <st data-num="03701" class="">silver</st> to <st data-num="01961" class="">gain</st> his <st data-num="03027 0854">support</st><n id="5" /> and to <st data-num="02388" class="">solidify</st> his <st data-num="03027" class="">control</st> of the <st data-num="04467" class="">kingdom</st>.<n id="6" />

Menahem got this silver by taxing all the wealthy men in Israel; he took 50 shekels of silver from each one of them and paid it to the king of Assyria. Then the king of Assyria left; he did not stay there in the land.
The rest of the events of Menahem’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
Menahem passed away and his son Pekahiah replaced him as king.
In the fiftieth year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Menahem’s son Pekahiah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for two years.
He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.

His officer Pekah son of Remaliah conspired against him. He and 50 Gileadites assassinated Pekahiah, as well as Argob and Arieh, in Samaria in the fortress of the royal palace. Pekah then took his place as king.
The rest of the events of Pekahiah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
In the fifty-second year of King Azariah’s reign over Judah, Pekah son of Remaliah became king over Israel. He reigned in Samaria for twenty years.
He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he did not repudiate the sinful ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat who encouraged Israel to sin.

<st data-num="03117" class="">During</st> <st data-num="06492" class="">Pekah’s</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">reign</st> over <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>, <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="08407" class="">Tiglath-Pileser</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">came</st> and <st data-num="03947" class="">captured</st> <st data-num="05859" class="">Ijon</st>, <st data-num="062" class="">Abel Beth Maacah</st>, <st data-num="03239" class="">Janoah</st>, <st data-num="06943" class="">Kedesh</st>, <st data-num="02674" class="">Hazor</st>,<n id="1" /> <st data-num="01568" class="">Gilead</st>, and <st data-num="01551" class="">Galilee</st>, including <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="0776" class="">territory</st> of <st data-num="05321" class="">Naphtali</st>. He <st data-num="01540" class="">deported</st> the people<n id="2" /> to <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st>.
Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah son of Remaliah. He assassinated him and took his place as king, in the twentieth year of the reign of Jotham son of Uzziah.
The rest of the events of Pekah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
In the second year of the reign of Israel’s King Pekah son of Remaliah, Uzziah’s son Jotham became king over Judah.

He <st data-num="01961" class="">was</st> <st data-num="06242" class="">twenty</st>-<st data-num="02568" class="">five</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">years</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">old</st> when he began to <st data-num="04427" class="">reign</st>, and he <st data-num="04427" class="">reigned</st> for <st data-num="08337 06240">sixteen</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">years</st> in <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>.<n id="1" /> His <st data-num="08034 0517">mother</st> was <st data-num="03388" class="">Jerusha</st> the <st data-num="01323" class="">daughter</st> of <st data-num="06659" class="">Zadok</st>.
He did what the Lord approved, just as his father Uzziah had done.
But the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places. He built the Upper Gate to the Lord’s temple.
The rest of the events of Jotham’s reign, including his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
In those days the Lord prompted King Rezin of Syria and Pekah son of Remaliah to attack Judah.
Jotham passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of his ancestor David. His son Ahaz replaced him as king.
